questions.text: Which of the following is not an anti-apoptotic protein?
questions.solution:
BAX and BAK are pro-apoptotic proteins.

They get inserted into the mitochondrial membrane and result in the formation of channels. This allows proteins from the inner mitochondrial membrane to leak out into the cytoplasm.

On the other hand, antiapoptotic proteins of the BCL2 family, like BCL-2 and BCL-XL limit the escape of proapoptotic mitochondrial proteins.

Related Pearl: Apoptotic genes

Group Members Details
Anti-apoptotlc BCL2,
BCL-XL

MCL1		 Present in outer mitochondrial membrane
Prevent leakage of cytochrome-c and
other death lnducing proteins into
cytosol.
Pro-apoptotlc BAX,
BAK		 On activation, they increase mitochondrial membrane permeability.
Stress Sensors BAD,
BIM,
BID,
Puma, Noxa		 Act as sensors of cellular stress and damage and regulate the balance
between the other two groups

questions.text: Which colour is imparted to Sudan IV when it is used to stain intracellular lipids?
questions.solution:
Sudan IV imparts a orange-red colour to the contained lipids.

Common special stains for lipids are:

  • Sudan dyes (Sudan Black B, Sudan III, Sudan IV)
  • Oil red O
  • Osmium tetroxide

Sudan Black B stains the lipids blue-black

Oil Red-O also imparts an orange-red color to the contained lipids.

Osmium tetroxide imparts brown black color to the lipids.(Electron microscopy)

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in Pathology and Microbiology

questions.text: Which amongst the following molecules play an important role in transmigration of leucocytes.
questions.solution:
CD31 (PECAM-1) helps in the transmigration of leucocytes across the wall of blood vessels.

Selectins (Both P&E) help in rolling; chemokines in activating the neutrophils to increase avidity of integrins; integrins help in firm adhesion.

questions.text: Neural Crest cells are present in?

choices.text: Scattered all over different areas of the brain

questions.solution:
Neural Crest cells have been identified in two areas of adult brains, the dentate gyrus of the hippocampus and the subventricular zone (SVZ).

The long-established dogma that no new neurons are generated in the brain of normal adult mammals is now known to be incorrect. Neural precursor cells are capable of generating neurons, astrocytes, and oligodendrocytes.

questions.text: Which of the following types of Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome is Autosomal Recessive?
questions.solution:
Kyphoscoliosis type(Type VI) is the most common autosomal recessive type and presents with Hypotonia, joint laxity, congenital scoliosis, ocular fragility.

Dermatosparaxsis type of the Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome is also autosomal recessive. All the other forms are Autosomal dominant.

Related Pearl: Ehler–Danlos Syndrome (EDS)

EDS Type Clinical Findings Inheritance Gene defects   Collagen Type
Classic  or type(I/II) Skin and joint hypermobility, atrophic scars, easy bruising  Autosomal dominant  COL5A1, COL5A2    Collagen type 5
Hypermobility or type (III) Joint hypermobility, pains, dislocations Autosomal dominant Unknown -
Vascular or type(IV) Thin skin, arterial or uterine rupture, bruising, small-joint hyperextensibility  Autosomal dominant COL3A1 Collagen type 3
Kyphoscoliosis or type (VI) Hypotonia, joint laxity, congenital scoliosis, ocular fragility Autosomal recessive PLOD1 lysyl hydroxylase-1
Arthrochalasia or type (VII a, b) Severe joint hypermobility, skin changes (mild), scoliosis, bruising Autosomal dominant COL1A1, COL1A2   Collagen type 1
Dermatosparaxis or type (VII c) Severe skin fragility, cutis laxa, bruising  Autosomal recessive  ADAMTS2  Procollagen N- peptidase

Related Pearl: Synthesis of collagen and its disorders

1. Collagen backbone Preprocollagen - Glycin-proline-lysine
2. Hydroxylation

Of proline and lysine in the presence of Vit C.

Deficiency of Vit C causes Scurvy.
3. Glycosylation Formation of procollagen and resulting triple helix
4. Cleavage of terminals of procollagen Resulting in the formation of tropocollagen
5. Cross-linking by lysyl oxidase (copper-containing enzyme)

Formation of mature collagen.

Defect causes Menkes disease and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome)

questions.text: All the following statements are true about the CDKN2A gene except?

choices.text: Decreased levels of the gene cause increased production of melanocytes
UVB irradiation inactivates the expression of the gene
It is a tumour suppressor gene

questions.solution:
UVB irradiation activates the expression of the CDKN2A gene. This causes a transient growth arrest that may allow repair of UVB-induced DNA damage before cell division.

The CDKN2A gene encodes for p16 and is a well known tumour suppressor gene, located on chromosome 9.

Hereditary or acquired defects in CDK4A  give rise to functional insufficiency of p16(INK4a) that permit the premature propagation of melanocytes harbouring potentially carcinogenic DNA damage.

questions.text:
A slide shows a neuron with a large amount of vacuoles, each representing a markedly distended lysosome filled with gangliosides, which stained positive for Sudan black B and a whorled configuration under an electron microscope.
Identify the condition?
questions.solution:
This slide is typical of Tay-sachs disease. The neurons are ballooned with cytoplasmic vacuoles, each representing a markedly distended lysosome filled with gangliosides.

With the electron microscope, several types of cytoplasmic inclusions can be visualized, the most prominent being whorled configurations within lysosomes composed of onion-skin layers of membranes.

In case of niemann-pick disease, cells become engorged with vacuoles, which are engorged secondary lysosomes that often contain membranous cytoplasmic bodies resembling concentric lamellated myelin figures, sometimes called “zebra” bodies.

Gaucher cells rarely appear vacuolated but instead have a fibrillary type of cytoplasm likened to crumpled tissue paper.

Related Pearl: Examples of Sphingolipidoses (Lipids-Storage Disease)

questions.text: All the following statements are true about Chédiak-Higashi syndrome except?

choices.text: It is a disorder of phagolysosomes
The gene associated with this disorder encodes a protein called LYST

questions.solution:
Chédiak-Higashi syndrome affects melanocytes causing albinism.

It is an autosomal recessive condition characterized by defective fusion of phagosomes and lysosomes in phagocytes and abnormalities in melanocytes, cells of the nervous system and platelets.

The gene associated with this disorder encodes a large cytosolic protein called LYST, which regulates lysosomal trafficking.

Related Pearl: Defects in Leukocyte Function

Disease

Defect

Leukocyte adhesion deficiency 1

Mutations in β chain of CD11/CD18 integrins

Leukocyte adhesion deficiency 2

Mutations in fucosyltransferase

Chediak–Higashi syndrome

Decreased leukocyte functions because of mutations affecting protein involved in lysosomal membrane traffic (LYST)

Chronic granulomatous disease

Defect in gene encoding phagocyte oxidase

Myeloperoxidase deficiency

Decreased microbial killing because of defective MPO-H2O2 system

questions.text: TP53 mutants can be discovered in the serum in all the following cancers except?
questions.solution:
In Bladder Cancer, TP53 mutants are found in Urine, and not in serum.

Meanwhile, Cell-Free DNA markers such as TP53 mutants are found in the serum in Colon, Lung and Pancreatic cancers.

questions.text: The following cells seen in the lymph node are indicative of
questions.solution:
The given slide is pathognomonic for measles. This is a slide of a lymph node biopsy showing a Warthin–Finkeldey giant cell with large grapelike clusters of inclusion bodies.

The lymphoid organs typically have marked follicular hyperplasia, large germinal centers, and randomly distributed multinucleate giant cells (Warthin-Finkeldey cells) which have eosinophilic nuclear and cytoplasmic inclusion bodies.

These are pathognomonic of measles and are also found in the lung and sputum.

questions.text: A gross specimen of the brain shows  yellow discoloration of the brain parenchyma due to bilirubin accumulation, which is most prominent in the basal ganglia deep to the ventricle. The condition that is most likely is?
questions.solution:
The gross section of the brain, is suggestive of Hydrops Fetalis, since its showing yellow discoloration of the brain parenchyma due to bilirubin accumulation, which is most prominent in the basal ganglia deep to the ventricle.

CNS damage due to Kernicterus is the most serious threat in fetal hydrops.

The affected brain is has a bright yellow color, particularly in the basal ganglia, thalamus, cerebellum, cerebral gray matter, and spinal cord.

Neural damage requires a blood bilirubin level greater than 20 mg/dL in term infants; in premature infants this threshold may be considerably lower.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: Herpes virus has been detected in atherosclerotic plaques
Early atherosclerotic lesions begin at sites of morphologically intact endothelium
Atherosclerotic ruptures are most common between 6PM and 12AM
Fatty streaks are the earliest lesions in atherosclerosis

questions.solution:
Atherosclerotic ruptures and consequent Infarctions are most common between 6AM and 12PM.

Adrenergic stimulation associated with waking and rising can increase systemic blood pressure, increasing the physical stresses on a given plaque. And is responsible for the circadian of acute myocardial infarction.

Early lesions begin at sites of morphologically intact but dysfunctional endothelium These show increased permeability, enhanced leukocyte adhesion, and altered gene expression.

Herpesvirus, cytomegalovirus, and Chlamydia pneumoniae have all been detected in atherosclerotic plaques but not in normal arteries.

questions.text: All the following can be associated with ‘blueberry muffin baby’ except?
questions.solution:
Measles is not associated with blueberry muffin baby.

Disseminated neuroblastomas, Rubella, Toxoplasmosis and other TORCH syndrome may present with multiple cutaneous metastases that cause deep blue discoloration of the skin called blueberry muffin baby.

questions.text: All of the following about Tetralogy of Fallot is false except:

choices.text: Clinical consequences depend on  the Ventricular Septal Defect
As the child grows the pulmonic orifice expands proportionally
Subpulmonary stenosis protects the pulmonary vasculature from pressure overload
Complete surgical repair is possible for TOF with pulmonary atresia

questions.solution:
The subpulmonary stenosis, protects the pulmonary vasculature from pressure overload, and right ventricular failure is rare.

The clinical consequences depend on the severity of the subpulmonary stenosis, as this determines the direction of blood flow and cyanosis. In infants with mild degrees of right ventricular obstruction often cyanosis is not present at birth. In infants with severe degrees of right ventricular obstruction neonatal cyanosis is noted immediately.

As the child grows and the heart increases in size, the pulmonic orifice does not expand proportionally, making the obstruction progressively worse.

Complete surgical repair is possible for classic TOF but is more complicated for persons with pulmonary atresia and dilated bronchial arteries and may require multiple surgeries as the age progresses.

questions.text: The morphologic hallmark of nonrheumatic, calcific aortic stenosis is?

choices.text: Heaped-up calcified masses within the aortic cusps
Involvement of the free edges of the cusps preventing opening
Functional valve area is increased by large nodular calcific deposits

questions.solution:
The morphologic hallmark of nonrheumatic, calcific aortic stenosis is heaped-up calcified masses within the aortic cusps that ultimately protrude through the outflow surfaces into the sinuses of Valsalva, preventing the opening of the cusps.

The free edges of the cusps are usually not involved. Functional valve area is decreased by large nodular calcific deposits, causing obstruction to outflow.

In contrast to rheumatic and congenital aortic stenosis, commissural fusion is not usually seen.

Note: 

Calcific Aortic Stenosis is the most common of all valvular abnormalities

questions.text: The structure marked by the arrow shows which of the following?
questions.solution:
Döhle bodies are patches of dilated endoplasmic reticulum see in neutrophils that appear as sky-blue cytoplasmic “puddles.”

In sepsis or severe inflammatory disorders (Ex: Kawasaki disease), leukocytosis is often accompanied by morphologic changes in the neutrophils, such as toxic granulations, Döhle bodies, and cytoplasmic vacuoles.

Russell bodies are eosinophilic, homogeneous immunoglobulin-containing cytoplasmic inclusions found in a plasma cell with an excessive synthesis of immunoglobulin.

Pappenheimer bodies are abnormal basophilic granules of iron found inside red blood cells composed of ferritin aggregates, or mitochondria containing aggregated ferritin.

Heinz bodies are inclusion bodies in red blood cells composed of denatured haemoglobin.

questions.text: CD 45 is present on which of the following WBCs?
questions.solution:
CD45 is present on all leucocytes and is known as leukocyte common antigen (LCA).

Mature T-Cells have CD3 and CD5.

Mature B-Cells have CD19, CD21 and CD23.

NK cells have CD16 and CD56.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true about Polycythemia Vera (PCV)?
1. Serum erythropoietin levels are low
2. In about 2% of patients, PCV transforms into ALL
questions.solution:
Since Polycythemia Vera is a form of primary Polycythemia, the erythropoietin levels are very low whereas secondary forms of polycythemia have high erythropoietin levels. The progenitor cells have markedly decreased requirements for erythropoietin and other hematopoietic growth factors due to constitutive JAK2 signaling.

In about 2% of patients, PCV transforms to AML whereas transformation to ALL is rarely observed. In fact, the interesting point is, this AML clone often lacks JAK2 mutations.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about Kaposi Sarcoma (KS)?

choices.text: KS has red-purple macules typically on the proximal lower extremities
HHV-8 acts as a cofactor in the progression of KS in HIV patients
Human Herpesvirus 8 is a necessary for development of KS
In African KS, numerous skin lesions are present

questions.solution:
Human Herpesvirus 8 is a necessary for development of KS.

HIV acts as a cofactor for tumor progression, but identity of cofactor in non-HIV KS is controversial.

Patches are red to purple macules seen on distal lower extremities which progress to raised plaques and the ultimately to nodules.

In african KS also called lymphadenopathic KS, skin lesions are sparse and patients instead present with lymphadenopathy.

Related Pearl: Classification of Kaposi sarcoma

Classic

  • Older men of eastern European and Meditteranean origin
  • Not associated with HIV
  • Skin plaques and nodules

Endemic African

  • Seen in HIV seronegative individuals
  • Predominant lymph node and visceral involvement

Transplant associated

  • Solid organ transplant recipients
  • Involves lymph nodes, mucosa, and viscera
  • Cutaneous lesions may be absent

AIDS-associated epidemic KS

  • HIV infected individuals
  • Involves lymph nodes

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about Immunohemolytic anemia?

choices.text: Warm Antibody Type is the most common form of immunohemolytic anemia
Cold Hemolysin Type has IgM Antibodies active below 37°C
Artificial mechanical cardiac valves cause more trauma than the porcine valves
Cold agglutinin antibodies appear transiently after infection with M. pneumoniae

questions.solution:
Cold Hemolysin Type has IgG(Not IgM) Antibodies active below 37°C.

  • Warm antibody type is the most common form of immune hemolytic anemia. 50% are idiopathic (primary); the others have a predisposing condition like SLE, lymphoid neoplasms or exposure to a drug.
  • Significant hemolysis caused by trauma to red cells is with cardiac valve prostheses and microangiopathic disorders. Artificial mechanical cardiac valves cause more trauma than bioprosthetic porcine valves.
  • Cold agglutinin antibodies(IgM) sometimes appear transiently following certain infections, such as with Mycoplasma pneumoniae, EBV, CMV, influenza virus, and HIV.

Immuno Hemolytic Anemias are of 3 types:

  1. Warm antibody type- IgG antibodies against Rh blood group antigens on the RBC surface at 37°C
  2. Cold agglutinin type- IgM antibodies bind to red cells below 37°C
  3. Cold hemolysin type- IgG antibodies bind to P blood group antigen on RBC surface below 37°C

questions.text: Which is true regarding pernicious anemia?

choices.text: Elevated levels of homocysteine and decreased methylmalonic acid in the serum
Four types of antibodies can be present in the serum
Tapeworms can exacerbate a B12 deficiency state
Folate therapy should be initiated first

questions.solution:
Tapeworms compete with the host for B12 and can induce a deficiency state.

Vit B12 is involved in 2 biochemical reactions:

  1. As a cofactor in the conversion of homocysteine to methionine (for DNA synthesis)
  2. Isomerization of methylmalonyl coenzyme A to succinyl coenzyme A (for normal myelination of neurons)

Folic acid is involved only in 1st reaction, not 2nd one.

In B12 deficiency – Both Homocysteine and Methylmalonic acid are elevated.

In Folate deficiency – Only Homocysteine is elevated, no neurological deficits.

Three types of autoantibodies are present in Pernicious anemia

  • Type I antibody -  blocks the binding of vitamin B12 to intrinsic factor. 
  • Type II antibodies - prevent binding of the intrinsic factor – vitamin B12 complex to its ileal receptor.
  • Type III antibodies - recognize and bind to the α and β subunits of the gastric proton pump.

B12 deficiency should be excluded first before initiating folate therapy in megaloblastic anemia. Because Hematologic symptoms of vitamin B12 deficiency anemia also respond to folate therapy. However, folate does not prevent (and may even exacerbate) the neurologic deficits.

questions.text: Which is the most common form of plasma cell dyscrasia?
questions.solution:
Monoclonal Gammopathy of Uncertain Significance (MGUS) is the most common plasma-cell dyscrasia. It  occurring in about 3% of persons older than 50 years of age and in about 5% of individuals older than 70 years of age.

POEMS (polyneuropathy, organomegaly, endocrinopathy, monoclonal gammopathy, and skin changes) syndrome is a rare paraneoplastic condition associated with a plasma-cell dyscrasia.

MGUS Smouldering Myeloma Multiple Myeloma
Asymptomatic Asymptomatic Symptomatic
M protein in serum <3g/dL

M-protein in serum:

  • IgG ≥3 g/dL,
  • IgA >1 g/dL
 M protein in serum and urine
Bone Marrow (BM) plasma cells <10% BM plasma cells 10-60% BM plasma cells >10%
No other organ or tissue impairment No other organ or tissue impairment Related impairment is seen.
(CRAB)

*CRAB –

  • HyperCalcemia: >1mg/dL higher than the upper limit of normal or >11mg/dL
  • Renal insufficiency: Creatinine >2 mg/dL
  • Anemia: Hemoglobin <10 g/dL or 2 g/dL <normal
  • Bone lesions: one or more osteolytic lesion on skeletal radiography, computed tomography (CT), or positron-emission tomography (PET)/CT.

questions.text: The Reid Index is:

choices.text: Ratio of the thickness of the mucous gland layer to the thickness of the bronchial wall
Ratio of the thickness of the mucous gland layer to the thickness of the cartilage

questions.solution:
Reid Index is the ratio of the thickness of the mucous gland layer to the thickness of the bronchial wall (between the epithelium and the cartilage).

It is normally 0.4 and is increased in chronic bronchitis, usually in proportion to the severity and duration of the disease.

questions.text: A pathologist is examining the following histopathological specimen from a patient with watery diarrhea and abdominal pain. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given histopathological image shows superficially damaged crypts with a typical pattern of mucopurulent exudates (neutrophils) emanating from a crypt that resembles a volcanic eruption. This is pathognomonic of Clostridium difficile colitis.

In this condition, disruption of the normal colonic microbiota by antibiotics allows C. difficile overgrowth. 

Risk factors for Clostridium difficile colitis are:

  • Antibiotic use
  • Advanced age
  • Gastric suppression- PPIs, H2 receptor blockers
  • Immunosuppression

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about Peliosis hepatis?

choices.text: It is a primary sinusoidal dilatation of liver
It is associated with Tuberculosis, AIDS and cancers
Clinical signs are absent even in advanced peliosis
Brucella species have been seen in the sinusoidal endothelial cells in AIDS-associated peliosis

questions.solution:
Peliosis hepatis: Peliosis hepatis is a distinct form of sinusoidal dilation.

Primary sinusoidal dilatation of liver is due to conditions which impede efflux of hepatic blood in liver results in blood-filled sinusoids/ cystic spaces in the liver 

Peliosis is also found in patients with Tuberculosis, AIDS,  posttransplantation immunodeficiency and Sex hormone administration (anabolic steroids, OCPs, Danazol) 

Bartonella species have been seen in the sinusoidal endothelial cells in AIDS-associated peliosis.

Clinical signs are often absent even in advanced stages, but potentially fatal intra-abdominal hemorrhage or hepatic failure may occur.

Peliotic lesions usually disappear after correction of the underlying causes.

questions.text: A 31-year-old man presented with a history of recurrent UTIs and hematuria. Urine culture showed growth of E. coli. Flexible cystoscopy revealed yellow-brown soft plaques with a central umbilication. Microscopy of the plaque showed Michaelis-Gutmann bodies. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario with the presence of Michaelis-Gutmann bodies is suggestive of malakoplakia.

Malakoplakia is a chronic inflammatory reaction resulting from acquired defects in phagocyte function, commonly affecting the urinary bladder. It can also be seen in other organ systems like the gastrointestinal tract, female genital tract, and central nervous system.

It is seen in chronic bacterial infection, mostly by Escherichia coli or occasionally Proteus species.  

Grossly, it presents as soft, yellow-brown, slightly raised mucosal plaques. Microscopically, the following findings are seen:

  • Large, foamy macrophages containing -
    • Abundant granular cytoplasm due to undigested bacterial products
    • Michaelis-Gutmann bodies - PAS-positive basophilic concretions due to iron and calcium deposits in lysosomes
  • Occasional multinucleated giant cells and lymphocytes

Note: Xanthogranulomatous cystitis is morphologically and probably pathogenetically similar to malakoplakia, but it lacks Michaelis–Gutmann bodies.

Related Pearl: Pathological Named Bodies

Bodies Found in
Asteroid bodies Sarcoidosis, Sporotrichosis

Henderson–Paterson bodies Molluscum contagiosum

Cowdry type-B bodies Adenovirus, poliovirus
Rusell bodies Multiple myeloma 
Aschoff bodies Rheumatic fever 
Call–Exner bodies Granulosa cell tumor of the ovary 
Civatte (colloid) bodies Lichen planus 
Michaelis–Gutmann bodies Malakoplakia 
Lewy bodies Parkinson's disease 
Pappenheimer bodies Non-heme iron pigments in siderocytes 
Howell–Jolly bodies Splenectomy, Megaloblastic Anemia, Hemolytic anemia 
Heinz bodies G-6-PD deficiency 
Gamna–Gandy bodies Congestive splenomegaly 
Mallory bodies Hyaline inclusions in hepatocytes seen in alcoholic cirrhosis, Indian childhood cirrhosis
Councilman bodies Hepatocytes undergoing apoptosis, seen mainly in acute viral hepatitis.
Psammoma bodies Dystrophic calcification in meningioma, papillary serous cystadenoma of ovary & papillary carcinoma of thyroid, papillary type of renal cell carcinoma.
Donovan bodies Granuloma inguinale 
Nissl's bodies Cytoplasmic inclusions in neurons 
Mooser bodies Typhus fever
Creola bodies Asthma 
Verocay bodies Schwannoma 
Schiller–Duval bodies Endodermal sinus tumor 

Hirano bodies

  Alzheimer’s disease

Ferruginous bodies

 Asbestosis

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs)?

choices.text: They prevent the spread of the microbes by trapping them in the fibrils
Nuclear chromatin in the NETs are the source of nuclear antigens in SLE
In sepsis, platelet activation is involved in NET formation
NETs play a major role in phagocytosis

questions.solution:
Neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs) are not involved in phagocytosis. This is because the nuclei of the neutrophils are lost during NET formation, leading to their death. Hence, they cannot phagocytose pathogens.

NETs are networks of extracellular fibers that consist of a viscous meshwork of nuclear chromatin. They trap microbes at sites of infection, preventing their further spread. They also contain a high concentration of antimicrobial proteins like neutrophil elastase, cathepsin G, and histones that have a high affinity for DNA.

They are produced by neutrophils in response to the following triggers:

  • Pathogens - Mainly bacteria and fungi
  • Inflammatory mediators -
    • Chemokines
    • Cytokines (mainly interferons)
    • Complement proteins
    • Reactive oxygen species

NETs have also been detected in the blood during sepsis. In this condition, platelet activation is involved in NET formation

The nuclear chromatin in the NETs is a source of nuclear antigens (histones and associated DNA) in systemic autoimmune diseases, particularly systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). This triggers autoantibody production and further clinical manifestations.

questions.text:
Which of the following traits are examples of co-dominance inheritance?
  1. ABO blood group
  2. Hair colour
  3. Height
  4. Skin color
  5. HLA
questions.solution:
ABO blood group and HLA are both examples of codominant inheritance.

In a codominant phenotype, alleles of a gene pair in a heterozygote are fully expressed. Thereby resulting in an offspring with a phenotype that is neither dominant nor recessive and both the alleles of a gene pair contributes to the phenotype.

Mendelian traits are usually described as dominant or recessive:

  • A dominant allele produces a dominant phenotype in individuals who have one copy of the allele, which can come from just one parent.
  • A recessive allele produces a recessive phenotype, in individuals who have two copies of the allele, one from each parent.

The illustration below shows the codominant inheritance pattern of the blood group.

Hair colour, height, and skin color are polygenic traits.

questions.text: Which of the following occurs due to gain-of-function mutations in NOD-Like receptors?
questions.solution:
The gain of function mutations in NOD-Like receptors (NLRs) result in periodic fever syndromes called autoinflammatory syndromes.

They are a group of clinical conditions characterised by recurrent inflammatory episodes. This disorder is marked by abnormally increased inflammation, mediated predominantly by cells and molecules of the innate immune system, with a significant host predisposition. 

NOD-like receptors are cytosolic receptors that signal via a cytosolic multiprotein complex called the inflammasome. This activates caspase-1 that generates biologically active form of interleukin-1 (IL-1). IL-1 is a mediator of inflammation that recruits leukocytes and induces fever. The autoinflammatory syndromes respond very well to treatment with IL-1 antagonists.

Note: Autoimmune diseases result from T and B-lymphocyte reactions against self-antigens.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of lobular breast carcinoma?
questions.solution:
There is no or very slight desmoplastic response seen in lobular carcinomas. 

Desmoplasia refers to collagenous stromal proliferation induced by tumor cells which is essential for tumor growth and spread. It results in hard and stony tumors. However, this is not seen in lobular carcinoma. This is likely due to the loss of expression of CDH1, the gene that encodes e-cadherin (normally maintains intercellular adhesiveness). This also results in disaggregation of cells.

Lobular carcinomas are often bilateral and multicentric. It shows characteristic metastatic spread, often involving:

  • Peritoneum and retro­ peritoneum
  • Leptomeninges (carcinomatous meningitis)
  • Gastrointestinal tract
  • Ovaries
  • Uterus

Histopathological image of invasive lobular carcinoma of breast showing discohesive cells with few signet ring cells.

Note: Individuals with heterozygous germline mutations in CDH1 (loss of E-cadherin) also have a greatly increased risk of gastric signet-ring cell carcinoma.

questions.text: Which tumor is a part of the paraneoplastic syndrome called Leser-Trélat sign?
questions.solution:
Seborrheic keratoses may suddenly appear in large numbers as part of a paraneoplastic syndrome known as Leser–Trélat sign.

It is possibly due to the stimulation of keratinocytes by transforming growth factor-α (TGF-α), which is produced by tumor cells, most commonly from carcinomas of the gastrointestinal tract.

Histological image of Seborrhic keratosis composed of benign basaloid cells associated with prominent keratin-filled “horn” cysts. Variable melanin pigmentation is present within these basaloid cells, accounting for the brown coloration.

questions.text: Which of these are the earliest morphologic markers of neuronal cell death?
questions.solution:
Red neurons are the earliest morphologic markers of neuronal cell death.

Acute neuronal injury refers to a spectrum of changes that accompany acute CNS hypoxia / ischemia or other acute insults and reflect the earliest morphologic markers of neuronal cell death. They are evident by about 12 to 24 hours after an irreversible insult.

Morphologic features consist of:

  • Shrinkage of the cell body
  • Pyknosis of the nucleus
  • Disappearance of the nucleolus
  • Loss of Nissl substance
  • Intense eosinophilia of the cytoplasm.

Stages of neuronal injury and their pathological features are given below:

Stages Time Features 
Early change 12–24 hr Red neuron
Subacute change 24 hr–2 weeks Necrosis, macrophages, vascular proliferation, gliosis
Repair 2 weeks + Removal of necrosis, gliosis completed, loss of CNS architecture

questions.text: The following histological image depicts a pathology in which of the following sites?
questions.solution:
The given histopathological image shows benign papillary projections covered with columnar secretory epithelium and underlying myoepithelial cells. These are commonly seen in papillary hidradenoma of the vulva.

It presents as a sharply circumscribed nodule, most commonly on the labia majora or interlabial folds. Like the breast, the vulva also contains modified apocrine sweat glands. Its histologic appearance is identical to that of intraductal papilloma of the breast.

questions.text: What percentage of platelets does the spleen normally sequester?
questions.solution: The spleen normally sequesters 30% to 35% of platelets. This can rise to 80% to 90% when the spleen is enlarged, producing moderate degrees of thrombocytopenia.

questions.text: Which of the following cells secretes VIP in pancreas?
questions.solution:
Vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP) is secreted by D1 cells in the endocrine pancreas.

Endocrine pancreas consists of islets of Langerhans, which contain four major and two minor cell types.

  • Four main types are β, α, δ, and PP (pancreatic polypeptide) cells:
    • α cells secrete glucagon, which stimulates glycogenolysis in the liver and thus increases blood sugar.
    • β cells produce insulin, which regulates glucose utilization in tissues and reduces blood glucose levels.
    • δ cells secrete somatostatin, which suppresses both insulin and glucagon release.
    • PP cells secrete pancreatic polypeptide, which exerts several gastrointestinal effects, such as stimulation of secretion of gastric and intestinal enzymes and inhibition of intestinal motility. These cells not only are present in islets but are also scattered in the exocrine pancreas.
  • Minor cell types:
    • D1 cells secrete VIP, a hormone that induces glycogenolysis and hyperglycemia; it also stimulates gastrointestinal fluid secretion and causes secretory diarrhea.
    • Enterochromaffin cells synthesize serotonin and are the source of pancreatic tumors that cause the carcinoid syndrome.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes with complaints of double vision that gets worse after she reads a book or watches television. She also has drooping of the eyelids that gets better after a nap. Serology is positive for anti-acetylcholine receptor antibodies. Which of the following is more commonly associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of myasthenia gravis. It is most commonly associated with thymic hyperplasia (65% of cases).

Thymoma is seen in around 10% of patients with myasthenia gravis.

Myasthenia gravis is a neuromuscular disorder that is characterized by weakness and the fatigability of skeletal muscles. It is due to the autoantibody-mediated destruction of the acetylcholine receptors (AChRs) at the neuromuscular junction. This consequentially leads to a decreased transmission at the neuromuscular (myoneural) junction. 

There is a characteristic pattern of muscle involvement. Lid and extraocular muscles (diplopia and ptosis) are involved early in the disease course. The facial muscles weakness can produce a snarling expression, weakness in chewing, and nasal timbre to the voice. Weakness increases with repeated use of the muscles and improves with rest. The reflexes are normal in this condition.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl who was evaluated for short height was found to have an enlarged pituitary gland. Her T4 was low and TSH was increased. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The child has low T4 and high thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH). The most likely diagnosis is primary hypothyroidism because primary hypothyroidism is associated with high TSH with low T4. It is due to defects in the thyroid gland itself.

Other options:

  • In cases of TSH-secreting pituitary tumor, increased TSH with increased T3 and T4 would be seen.
  • In thyroid hormone resistance, increased T4 as well as T3 with unsuppressed TSH will be seen.
  • In toxic adenoma, T4 is high and TSH is low.

questions.text:
Mesangial deposits are seen in which of the following conditions?
  1. Henoch-Schönlein purpura
  2. Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis
  3. Alport syndrome
  4. Berger disease
  5. Membranous nephropathy
questions.solution:
Mesangial deposits are seen in the following conditions:

  • IgA nephropathy (Berger disease)
  • Henoch–Schonlein purpura
  • Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis
  • Lupus nephritis classes I and II
  • Resolving postinfectious  glomerulonephritis

Related Pearl: Sites of Deposits in Glomerular diseases

Subepithelial
  • Membranous nephropathy (epimembranous)
  • PSGN
Intramembranous
  • Dense deposit disease (MPGN type II)
Subendothelial
  • MPGN Type I
  • Lupus nephritis class III and IV
Mesangial
  • IgA nephropathy
  • Henoch–Schonlein Purpura
  • RPGN 
  • Lupus nephritis classes I and II
  • Resolving postinfectious  glomerulonephritis
No deposits
  • Minimal change disease
  • FSGS
  • Alport syndrome

MPGN: Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis

PSGN: Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis 

FSGS: Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis

RPGN: Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis

questions.text: In which condition is Alzheimer type II astrocyte seen?
questions.solution:
Alzheimer type II astrocyte is seen in hepatic encephelopathy.

Alzheimer type II astrocyte (unrelated to Alzheimer disease but first described by the same individual):

  • It is a grey-matter cell with a large nucleus, pale-­staining central chromatin, an intranuclear glycogen droplet, and a prominent nuclear membrane and nucleolus.
  • It is mainly seen in individuals with long-­standing hyperammonemia due to chronic liver disease, Wilson disease, or hereditary metabolic disorders of the urea cycle.
  • In gliosis, astrocytes are called gemistocytic astrocytes.
  • In hepatic encephalopathy, astrocytes with enlarged nuclei and minimal reactive cytoplasm (known as Alzheimer type II cells) appear in the cerebral cortex, basal ganglia, and other subcortical gray-matter regions.

questions.text: You are collecting a blood sample to send for prothrombin time in a patient in the ward. Which of the following is true about this investigation?

choices.text: Test must be done within 2 hours of sample collection

questions.solution:
The test for prothrombin time is done within 2 hours.

The differences between PT and aPTT are:

Feature PT aPTT
Coagulation pathway tested Extrinsic and common Intrinsic and common
Normal value 11-13 seconds 25-35 seconds
Sample Platelet-poor plasma Platelet-poor plasma
Activating agent Thomboplastin

Kaolin

Silica

Ellagic acid

 

Related Pearl: Parameters of the coagulation pathway and its uses

 Parameters of the coagulation pathway and its uses

Parameter Uses
Prothrombin Time (PT) It is used to monitor the functioning of the extrinsic and the common coagulation pathways. Normal PT is 11–13 seconds.
Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) It is used to monitor the functioning of the intrinsic and the common coagulation pathways. Normal aPTT is 25–35 seconds. A relatively rare cause of prolonged aPTT is the presence of antibodies against coagulation plasma proteins called inhibitors. It can be seen due to the following reasons: Hemophilia A and B patients receiving clotting factors to control their bleeding episodes, Pregnancy, Autoimmune diseases, Malignancies (lymphoma, prostate cancer), and Dermatologic conditions.
Thrombin time (TT) It is used for testing the conversion of fibrinogen into fibrin and depends on adequate fibrinogen levels. 
Bleeding time (BT) It is the time taken for a standardized skin puncture to stop bleeding. It tests the ability of blood vessels to constrict and platelets to form a hemostatic plug. 
Fibrin degradation products (FDPs) They are used to assess the fibrinolytic activity, and they are increased in disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). 

Related Pearl: Coagulation Pathways and its Abnormalities

Test results Inherited causes Acquired causes

Prolonged PT 

Evaluates extrinsic pathway factors

Normal PT: 11-13 seconds

 Factor VII deficiency 

Mild vitamin K deficiency

Liver disease

Warfarin

Prolonged aPTT

Evaluates intrinsic pathway factors

Normal aPTT: 25-35 seconds

Factors VIII, IX, XI deficiency

Factor XII, prekallikrein, or HMW kininogen deficiency

von Willebrand disease

 Heparin, lupus anticoagulant, acquired von Willebrand disease

Prolonged PT + prolonged aPTT

Evaluates common pathway factors

Prothrombin (II), fibrinogen (I), factors V and factor X deficiencies

Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)

Severe liver disease

Severe vitamin K deficiency

Direct thrombin inhibitor-argatroban, dabigatran

Direct factor Xa inhibitor-rivaroxaban, apixaban, edoxaban

Fondaparinux

questions.text: An 8-month-old child presents with mental retardation, blindness, and muscle weakness. On evaluation, deficiency of hexosaminidase α-subunit is found. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and hexosaminidase α-subunit deficiency are seen in Tay–Sachs disease.

Sphingolipidoses with their deficient enzyme:

  1. GM1 Gangliosidoses - GM1 Ganglioside β- galactosidase deficiency
    • Type 1- infantile, generalizsed
    • Type 2- juvenile
  2. GM2 Gangliosidosis:
    • Tay–Sachs disease - Hexosaminidase α-subunit
    • Sandhoff disease - Hexosaminidase β-subunit
    • GM2 Gangliosidosis variant AB - Ganglioside activator protein

Note: Tay–Sachs disease is the most common form of GM2 gangliosidosis.

Related Pearl: Lysosomal storage diseases

Lysosomal Storage Diseases Enzyme-deficient
Sphingolipidoses
Gaucher disease Glucocerebrosidase
Tay-Sachs disease Hexosaminidase A
Fabry disease α-galactosidase A
Krabbe disease

Galactocerebrosidase

(Galactosylceramidase)
Niemann-Pick disease Sphingomyelinase
Mucopolysaccharidoses  
Hurler syndrome α-L-iduronidase
Hunter syndrome Iduronate-2-sulfatase
Others:
Pompe disease Lysosomal acid α-1,4- glucosidase

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding mucinous tumors of the ovary?

choices.text: It occurs principally in middle adult life
Mutation of the KRAS proto-oncogene is seen

questions.solution:
The vast majority of mucinous tumors of the ovary are benign or borderline tumors (not malignant).

It occurs principally in middle adult life and is rare before puberty and after menopause. The surface of the ovary is rarely involved, they are rarely bilateral. It is associated with the mutation of KRAS proto-oncogene. 

Grossly it is multiloculated and filled with sticky, gelatinous fluid (rich in glycoproteins).

questions.text: What type of chemokine is MCP-1?
questions.solution:
MCP-1 belongs to the CC type of chemokine. Here, the first two conserved cysteine residues remain adjacent to each other.

The C­C chemokines include:

  1. Monocyte chemoattractant protein (MCP­1)
  2. Eotaxin
  3. Macrophage inflammatory protein­1α (MIP­1α)
  4. Regulated and normal T-­cell expressed and secreted (RANTES)

The image below shows the structure of C-C chemokine:

questions.text:
A patient presented to the emergency department with high fever, photophobia and neck stiffness. A lumbar puncture was performed and findings are given below. Which of the following is the most common cause of this condition?
CSF Parameters  Observation
Cell count 1500 (predominantly lymphocytes)
Protein 100 mg/dl
Glucose 40 mg/dl
Gram stain  Negative
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of aseptic meningitis. Enterovirus is the most common cause, accounting for around 90% of the cases.

Related Pearl: CSF findings in meningitis

questions.text: Histopathological examination of a biopsy taken from a rough, scaly macular lesion from a patient's forearm showed neoplastic dyskeratosis. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Neoplastic dyskeratosis is seen in actinic keratosis.

Dyskeratosis is premature keratinization of individual keratinocytes. These cells usually have pink or reddish cytoplasm. It can be benign or malignant:

  • Benign dyskeratosis - seen in Darier’s disease, warty dyskeratoma, and familial benign pemphigus
  • Neoplastic dyskeratosis - seen in Bowen’s disease, squamous cell carcinoma, and actinic keratosis

Actinic keratoses usually occur in sun-damaged skin and are considered precursor lesions of squamous cell carcinoma. Some lesions produce so much keratin that a cutaneous horn develops.

The image below shows the histology of actinic keratosis. It shows atypical basal cells, dyskeratotic cells, and parakeratosis in the stratum corneum (cells with a retained nucleus).

questions.text: Which of the following genetic changes is not associated with bladder carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Activating mutation in HRAS (not NRAS) is responsible for bladder carcinoma.

Genetic changes associated with carcinoma bladder:

  • Noninvasive low-grade papillary urothelial carcinoma is associated with:
    • Gain-of-function mutations of FGFR3 and HRAS genes
    • Chromosome 9p and 9q deletions
  • High-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma (either papillary or flat) is associated with:
    • Loss-of-function mutations of TP53 and RB genes

Note: Erdafitinib (kinase inhibitor) is the first targeted drug therapy approved by the FDA for the treatment of metastatic urothelial carcinoma especially in patients with mutations of FGFR3 or FGFR2.

questions.text: Which thyroid carcinoma is associated with amyloid deposition?
questions.solution:
Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid is associated with amyloid deposition. It is an essential diagnostic feature of this carcinoma.

Microscopic deposits of localized amyloid may be found in certain conditions such as:

  • Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid gland
  • Islet tumors of the pancreas
  • Pheochromocytomas
  • Undifferentiated carcinomas of the stomach
  • Islets of Langerhans in individuals with type 2 diabetes mellitus

questions.text: The organ least likely to be involved in acute graft-versus-host disease reaction is ________
questions.solution:
Graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) affects the liver, skin and gut and is least likely to affect the adrenal glands amongst the given options.

GVHD occurs when immunologically competent cells or their precursors are transplanted into immunologically compromised recipients. The transferred cells recognize the alloantigens in the host and attack host tissues. It is seen most commonly during hematopoietic stem cell transplantation but may also occur following the transplantation of solid organs. 

GVHD may be of two types: acute and chronic.

Acute GVHD occurs within days to weeks after allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation. It mainly involves the immune system and the epithelia of the skin, liver, and intestines. But the affected tissues are not heavily infiltrated by lymphocytes. It may present as:

  • Generalized rash over the skin that may lead to desquamation
  • Destruction of small bile ducts in the liver giving rise to jaundice
  • Mucosal ulceration of the gut resulting in bloody diarrhea

Chronic GVHD may follow acute GVHD or may occur insidiously. Some patients even develop autoimmunity, owing to the grafted CD4+ helper T cells reacting with host B cells and stimulating them, which may result in autoantibody production. It may present as:

  • Destruction of skin appendages and fibrosis of the dermis resembling systemic sclerosis
  • Chronic liver disease manifested by cholestatic jaundice
  • Damage to the gastrointestinal tract may cause esophageal strictures
  • Involution of the thymus and depletion of lymphocytes in the lymph nodes with recurrent bouts of life-threatening infections.

Depletion of donor T cells by irradiation before transfusion can eliminate the occurrence of GVHD. But irradiation also has its adverse effects such as tumor recurrence in leukemic patients, increased incidence of graft failures, and EBV-related B-cell lymphoma.

Related Pearl: Transplant Rejection and Hypersensitivity

Type of Rejection  Type of Hypersensitivity

Host vs Graft
Hyperacute Type 2
Acute Type 2 and 4
Chronic Type 2 and 4
Graft vs Host
Graft vs host reaction Type 4

 

The image given below explains the pathophysiology of hyperacute graft rejection (type II hypersensitivity). 

The image below shows the mechanism of type IV hypersensitivity in graft rejection.

questions.text: A 1-month-old infant diagnosed with primary adrenal insufficiency presented with failure to thrive, recurrent emesis, and hepatosplenomegaly. Bilateral adrenal calcification was noted radiologically. Which of the following enzyme is deficient in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of Wolman disease. It is due to a deficiency of the lysosomal acid lipase enzyme. It is an autosomal recessive disease.

It leads to the accumulation of cholesterol esters and triglycerides. It presents in the first few weeks of life with:

  • Failure to thrive
  • Vomiting
  • Abdominal distention
  • Steatorrhea
  • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • Hyperlipidemia
  • Extensive bilateral calcifications of the adrenal glands

No specific therapy is available and death usually occurs within 6 months of life.

questions.text: Cholemic nephrosis is associated with which of the following casts?
questions.solution:
Cholemic nephrosis is associated with casts of bile.

In patients with acute or chronic liver disease with advanced liver failure, renal function may be impaired. This is called hepatorenal syndrome. This can be associated with highly elevated bilirubin levels with bile cast formation (also known as cholemic nephrosis) in distal nephron segments.

Related Pearl: Urinary Casts and Their Significance
